history.content:
Yes! Just like plenty of applied math, statistics, and cognitive science majors get software engineering jobs. If your goal is a software engineering job, a CS major would look better to recruiters, as most listing require a CS degree.

---

From my experience/job searching, most of the time your major doesn't really matter as long as you have the relevant (it certainly won't ~5 years into your career) experience (internships/projects) and skills, especially with a STEM degree from Berkeley. A CS major does not mean you're going to find a SWE job, if you lack the foundational knowledge and interview skills. So it's really not the end of the world if you can't declare CS or any other major, as long as you can back it up with the necessary skills (algorithms, data structures, etc.). I've seen Applied Math/stats majors get offers CS majors didn't, and vice versa. Just work on improving yourself as a programmer.

Yes! Just like plenty of applied math, statistics, and cognitive science majors get software engineering jobs. If your goal is a software engineering job, a CS major would look better to recruiters, as most listing require a CS degree.

children.subject: This kind of positive feedback really helps. I've been really been hard on myself and knowing that a major will not define where I will potentially work at makes me feel better.

I was messaging a recruiter from a big 4 type company about Data Science vs CS and here's what he said:

"Data Science is the new flavor du jour, but I'm not so sure what the UC degree itself is teaching. In my opinion it's really a mix of statistics and computer science, with some linear algebra thrown in. The Berkeley that I knew (keep in mind that was >30yrs ago) would have been very open to a student adapting the curriculum to suit his own interests. My gut tells me a properly managed CS curriculum is inherently worth more than a degree in Data Science, but a DS degree may be more marketable right now just because it is fashionable. When I was reviewing intern candidates for SWE positions at PayPal and Uber the DS majors we saw were Masters or PhD candidates. Some of them were very qualified for SWE positions and will have a bright future at these companies. There were others who were more versed in theory but couldn't code. The latter was a problem. The biggest challenge for DS today is that they weren't usually taught how to collect and process the data on their own. Usually DS relied on someone else to manage the data for them and that is very limiting, and I've been reluctant to hire DS candidates who cannot demonstrate the ability to manage their own data. That means a well rounded DS candidate should have data management skills (e.g., physical modeling, query language, python, hive, map-reduce, etc). Hope this helps."

So really, employability for Data Scientists comes down to how well they can code. I just have to hope that cal's DS allows the option of erring heavily on the CS side.

history.content: Looking at the course reqs, it seems like the requirements between the two majors are quite similar compared to the other backup majors(e.g- cs61A/B 170 186, etc).
history.subject: Would the new Data Science major work just as well as CS for software engineering jobs?
